awd_titl_txt: Conference: FOCS Conference Student and Postdoc Travel Support
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports student and postdoctoral fellow attendance at the IEEE Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS), to take place during October 31-November 3, 2022, in Denver, Colorado. FOCS is one of the two premier annual research conferences that cover the breadth of theoretical computer science. FOCS has a record of strongly encouraging participation by students, particularly those from under-represented groups. The conference serves as a valuable educational experience both for the technical content of the talks and for the opportunities for networking that it provides.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this grant, written in my role as the Chair of IEEE Computer Society Technical Committee on Mathematical Foundations of Computing (TCMF), is to assist students/postdocs to attend the  2022 Annual IEEE Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS) at Denver Colorado. The goal is to encourage and enable the participation of students/postdocs in cases where travel expenses would otherwise preclude their attendance. With priority given to support young scholars from under-represented groups, broadening the participation will benefit students in need as well as strengthen the long-term robustness and diversity of this top conference.

We received $15,000 from NSF for FOCS’21 (NSF 2204910).  However, the planning for in-person FOCS’21 and the subsequent FOCS’22 was eventful. Covid delayed FOCS’21 from the traditional October/November 2021 to February 2022. Omicron Spike then canceled the in-person conference two months prior and made it a virtual FOCS for the second year in a row. Omicron Spike also interrupted the planning of FOCS’22 at Durham, NC. Ultimately, FOCS’22 was moved to Denver Colorado.

Because FOCS’21 was forced to be a virtual conference, the conference organizers worked hard to reduce students’ registration fees. As the result, this FOCS’21 NSF Travel Account had a balance of $10,148, after supporting the registrations of 13 students (from eight different universities).  After discussing with the NSF program directors, we requested and received this NSF travel fund of amount $5000 for FOCS'22. The combined two NSF grants were used to support students/postdocs to attend FOCS’22, which was successfully held as the first in-person FOCS after Covid.

It has been a wonderful experience interacting with many talented young researchers in TCS and their advisors in many universities to understand their excitement about the research fields and their needs. I hope these experiences will contribute to future collaboration between NSF and TCS conferences, particular in areas of supporting NSF's goals for recruiting a diverse spectrum of participants.

Intellectual Merit:

With the rise of Internet and Big Data, computer science is now at the center of the many disciplines, from natural sciences to social sciences, from medicine to art, from engineering to policy. As these interactions emerging, theoretical computer scientists, particularly the younger generation, have taking great strides in advancing algorithmic/computational thinking beyond our traditional field. The NSF travel award have been making direct contribution to this generation.

IEEE FOCS is one of the two premier TCS conferences,  with long standing that has continued to play a formative role in the field; it is also at the leading edge of connections made to other fields.

For FOCS’22, we received a record high 47 applications. Because many advisors indicated that they would find ways to support their students, in case they didn’t receive any travel award, we were able to partly support all students/postdocs who had papers in FOCS 2022.. In total, we (partly) supported 37 students/postdocs from 20 different universities. 

We believe that the resultant discussions will expose the awardees to a broad set of fundamental questions and ideas. With strong aim to support young research from underrepresented groups and talented students beyond traditional TCS powerhouses, our goal is to broaden the participation to make FOCS an even more robust TCS conference. We expect the research community to benefit in turn, as such junior researchers have contributed substantially to the growth of theoretical computer science over the years.

 

Broader Impacts:

Build on the NSF FOCS travel grants, we also applied and received support from Akamai and Google.

 Working with TCS Women and a Google DEI grant that we received, we provided FULL support to 7 women applicants, including one African American and two Latina from Puerto Rico. By supporting applicants from more than 20 universities, the funds were widely distributed among many universities beyond just traditional TCS powerhouses.

Working with NSF and young researchers in this selection process provided us valuable experience to be more proactive in reaching out to TCS women community/organizations to encourage female theoretical computer scientists about future NSF FOCS travel grants. 

Many of the Ph.D. students/postdocs supported by NSF FOCS travel grants will be future leaders in computer science. Several have already made breakthrough discovery in algorithm design and computational complexity by solving long-term fundamental open questions. The NSF travel award, particular at this stage of their professional career, are critical support to their growth. In addition to help them to participate the premier conferences to benefit them and the research community, the application process also helped them to recognize how much their research are supported by not just their advisors/institutes, but by society in large.

Acknowledgement: USC Computer Science Department’s business office provided complimentary support for managing the entire process of reimbursements involving this NSF grant, so that all funds can be used for student/postdoc travel to attend FOCS. We greatly appreciate their contribution and generosity.
